BC-FEATURES-BJT23-COX 
    

      COX NEWS SERVICE FEATURES BUDGET
      c. 1999 Cox News Service

   These feature stories are moving today to clients of the New
York Times News Service. Stories are for release Friday, July 23,
1999, unless otherwise embargoed.

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   So specialty editors can focus on one day's budget, CoxNet
produces themed features budgets each day. Here is the schedule:

   Monday for Tuesday: Technology

   Tuesday for Wednesday: Automotive, personal finance and home &
garden

   Wednesday for Thursday: Food, CD reviews, video reviews

   TODAY: Movie reviews, travel, books and fashion

   Friday for Saturday: Religion and science & health

   In addition, separate budgets move daily with spot news, sports,
business and commentary.

   Stories are moving in the category they're listed under. Stories
moving to duplicate categories are marked. An ETA is given if a
story will move after 8 p.m. Eastern.

   If you have questions or need a resend, please call CoxNet, the
Cox News Service, at 404-526-5456.

   SAVE TIME: Stories marked as a CoxNet layout are available for
purchase in paginated form: www.nytsyn.com/pageexpress.

   LIFESTYLE

   JFK-FORKIDS _ Who was JFK Jr., and why should kids care that he
died? We try to explain the importance of the Kennedy family to
American politics and to history. (Focusing on Joe, JFK, Robert and
even Edward.) We also try to explain to the kids why their parents
or grandparents are upset about his death and how it impacts the
American culture. (Hendrick, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TRAVEL

   TRAVEL-CAPE _ HYANNISPORT, Mass. _ With the nation's attention
riveted on the Kennedy family's history, it's hard to remember that
there's lots more to draw tourists to Cape Cod. (Dart, Cox News
Service) WITH PHOTOS. (MOVED. Embargoed for Sunday, July 25.)

   COXNET TRAVEL _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Travel page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET TRAVEL 0720 -- On Hawaii's `Garden Island' of Kauai,
laid-back beauty flourishes alongside rugged canyons (Rice, Austin
American-Statesman) Art includes 4-column color photo of Anini
Beach and a 18-pica color photo of Lumahai Beach, and 18-pica color
illustration for headline treatment.

   WITH: ESSENTIALS OF KAUAI -- Tips for traveling in Kauai. Art
includes a 2-column color map illustration of the island of Kauai.

   WITH: IN PRINT -- Travel writer Bill Bryson takes a long,
strange trip back to his home country. (Shah, Austin
American-Statesman) Art includes 1-column color photo of book.

   WITH: TRAVEL BRIEFS -- Denmark has proclaimed 1999 its Medieval
Year, highlighting the many archeological digs, burial mounds,
churches and museums of that nation. (Staff, N.Y. Times News
Service)

   TRAVEL-YARDSALE _ Bruce Jones, of Pascagoula, Miss., surveyed
the wares on the lawn of the Jordan Motel near Jamestown, Tenn.,
during last year's ``World's longest Yard Sale'' _ 450 miles of
flotsam and jetsam stringing from Covington, Ky., to Gadsden, Ala.,
to Covington, Ky. ``I'm looking for the find of a lifetime,'' he
said. ``Of course, I don't know what that is.'' We preview this
year's sale, Aug. 19-22. (Walker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   EDS: Embargoed for Sunday, July 25.

   WITH

   TRAVEL-YARDTOUR _ A guide to the World's Longest Yard Sale,
unfurling from Covington, Ky., to Gadsden, Ala. It's the Grand Prix
for avid second-hand shoppers, though car speeds are more likely to
putter at 20 miles an hour rather than roar at 200. (Walker,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   EDS: Embargoed for Sunday, July 25.

   GETAWAY-FESTIVALS _ Southern happenings. (Thrasher, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   GETAWAY-BELLECHERE _ Asheville, N.C.'s Belle Chere, July 23-25,
is a three-day outdoor street festival with food, entertainment,
arts and crafts and family events. (Thrasher, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FASHION

   FASHION-PLUSSIZES _ ATLANTA _ The fashion industry is
discovering what many women have known all along: Hippy and buxom
women who wear double-digit sizes want to be stylish too. That's
why stores like Lane Bryant, Nordstrom, Ashley Stewart and August
Max are carrying designs that are hot and flattering to fuller
figures. (Hill, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS.
Embargoed for Sunday, July 25.

   STYLE-TRAVELTIPS _ Style File column from Meredith Moss includes
tips for efficient packing from seasoned travel veterans. (Dayton
Daily News). 31. WITH PHOTOS.

   HOME AND GARDEN

   GARDENING-LIFE _ A gardening column by Lee May. (May, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   NUTS&BOLTS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ While it's true that a $500 solid
wood panel door looks better than a $150 painted aluminum screen
door, I still think a screen door has a lot to recommend it. Screen
doors require some maintenance, but keeping them in good working
order is not difficult. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News)

   REBUILT-PIANO _ Greg Canty admits he can only peck at a piano.
His wife, Lynn, does not play at all. But the Alpharetta couple
noticed that their 9-year-old, Gregory, enjoyed baning out tunes at
his grandmother's hours, a skill the family wanted to foster. The
Canty's opted for a rebuilt piano, joining legoins of others in
Atlanta and across nation teaching their kids music lessons, as new
research shows music can enhace academic performance. (Lore,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   WORKSHOP-PAINTED-TILES _ This is the fifth installment on our
summer workshop series. This week: Painted tiles. (Flanders,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   TVCENTURY _ ATLANTA _ In the spring of the last year of the
century, a priest joked that if Jesus Christ returned for the
Second Coming, his first stop would be CNN headquarters in Atlanta.
The comment was fictional, in a novel titled ``Messiah'' by
Romanian poet Andrei Codrescu, but reality was working hard to make
such speculation seem reasonable. By the end of the century,
television had become more than a mere medium; it was the
uber-medium, the technology that ate the world. The single biggest
influence on what books people read was Oprah Winfrey's Book Club.
For years, the best guide for movie audiences had been the thumbs
of Roger Ebert and the late Gene Siskel on their TV show. TV ads
directed us on how to choose our telephone service, our computers,
our web portals and, of course, or TV shows. (Kloer, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Embargoed for Sunday, July 25.

   TVCENTURY-FUTURE _ ATLANTA _ The next revolution in TV, the
digital revolution, has already begun even if consumers haven't
noticed or cared much yet. (Kloer, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
Embargoed for Sunday, July 25.

   RADIO _ AUSTIN, Texas _ You're listening to the radio in Temple
or Hawaii and you think the friendly DJ playing music and chatting
is right there in your hometown. Wrong. If it's a Star System
station the DJ is sitting in a state-of-the-art digital radio booth
on Congress Avenue in Austin and faking it for different towns. We
feature the operation and discuss the issue of non-local radio.
(Smith, Austin American-Statesman) WITH PHOTOS.

   EMMYS _ Analysis and list of Emmy Award nominations. (Jubera,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TVTOUR _ HOLLYWOOD _ News and notes from Day 2 of Fox. (Kloer,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   NDEGECELLO _ Shortish profile or Q&A with Me'Shell Ndegecello,
who has been out of the loop for about 3 years, and returns to
performing this weekend with Lilith Fair. (Murray, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   TICKET-PRICES _ ATLANTA _ What's happening to concert ticket
prices? Top dollar for Whitney Houston's concerts at the Fox this
week are $125. Ricky Martin is charging $97. When did this trend
start? what is fueling it? who's paying these prices? why? We
attempt to answer this questions by talking to concert promoters,
industry observers, real people and acts themselves. (Longino,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED

   MOVIE-DROPDEAD _ Movie review of ``Drop Dead Gorgeous,'' a
satire of beauty contests. Grade: B-. It's a mean-spirited but
often funny spoof. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MOVIE-GADGET _ Movie review of ``Inspector Gadget'' with Matthew
Broderick. (Longino, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MOVIE-HAUNTING _ Movie review of ``The Haunting,'' Jan De Bont's
remake of Robert Wise's 1963 horror classic. It's about a research
group that spends jittery nights in a haunted mansion. (Murray,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   GADGETS _ Inspecting gadgets: we take a look at our favorite
gadgets in movies. (Batman's belt, Darth Maul's sword, etc.) (Palm
Beach Post)

   MOVIE-GADGET _Review of Inspector Gadget (one star). (Passy,
Palm Beach Post)

   THEWOOD _ The hip-hop music and catchphrases of the '80s make a
strong comeback in ``The Wood,'' the nostalgic film about a trio of
black friends reminiscing about their early teen days in Inglewood,
Calif. We talk to local moviegoers about the film's touchstones
like jheri curls, K-Swiss tennis shoes, flat top hair cuts, and
Spandex. They sometimes cause audience members to unexpectedly
blurt out, ``I remember that!'' (Longino, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED

   WITH

   THEWOOD-DIGGS _ Q&A with Taye Diggs (``How Stella Got Her Groove
Back.'' ``Go''), who stars in the new film ``The Wood'' as the pal
about to get married. (Harris, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED

   THEWOOD-BLACKDADS _ ``The Wood,'' a top 10 film described as a
black ``Big Chill,'' is full of family references. But it has an
odd quirk: There are no fathers present, or even mentioned. Lyle
Harris, himself a black father, columnizes. (Harris, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   MOVIES-MINIREVIEWS _ Mini reviews of all currently playing
movies. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   COXNET ENTERTAIN _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet ENTERTAIN page for
the current week. This layout available today after 2 p.m. EDT.)

   COXNET ENTERTAINMENT 0722 _ Terror is playing mind games at the
movies this summer. Fresh-meat horror is taking a holiday. And in
its place comes psychological trepidation _ terrible things that go
bump in the night, unseen or mere glimpses of monsters, panic,
disorientation and primal fears. (Longino, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   WITH: HORROR LIST _ A list of 10 classic horror films available
on video.

   WITH: RINGEL ON VIDEO _ In celebration of Hemingway's birthday,
here are some Heminway works on film that prove Papa's legacy still
lived on. (Ringel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WITH: VIDEO REVIEWS _ Director John Boorman is back in fine form
with ``The General,'' a character study of celebrated Irish
criminal Martin Cahill.

   WITH: CD REVIEWS _ For awhile, it looked as if ``Tigermilk''
would remain a Belle and Sebastian fan's scratchy fifth-generation
cassette or a collector's holy grail. Thankfully, the band decided
otherwise and released the work on CD. Also, reviews of Doria
Roberts' new release and the soundtrack to ``The Wood.'' (Staff,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   COXNET BOOKS _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Books page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET BOOKS 0720 -- A new biography portrays the strong
political partner who worked at LBJ's side despite personal
affronts and public challenges. (Morris, Austin American-Statesman)
Art includes 3-column color photo of Lady Bird Johnson and 6-pica
color photo of book jacket.

   WITH: REVIEW: BEETLE POWER -- Two coffee-table books tell the
complete story of the VW Beetle, the car that became an icon.
(Brock, N.Y. Times News Service) Art includes 2 6-pica color photos
of book jackets and a 2-column color photo of the new VW Beetle.

   WITH: MANNERS -- In ``A Short History of Rudeness: Manners,
Morals and Misbehavior in Modern America,'' Mark Caldwell dwells on
subjects that seem to fit better in a general social history than a
particular history of manners. (Eder, N.Y. Times News Service) Art
includes 6-pica color photo of book jacket.

   WITH: SUMMER READING -- Short takes on latest nonfiction
releases of note. (Harrison, Cox News Service)

   WITH: N.Y. TIMES BEST SELLERS LIST

   BOOK-CARAVAGGIO _ Review of Helen Langdon's ``Caravaggio: A
Life.'' (Brock, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Embargoed for Sunday,
July 25.

   SKUBE-ON-BOOKS _ There are times, to paraphrase Thomas Paine,
when the soul is tried beyond ``goshamighty,'' ``dadgummit'' and
even ``friggin'.'' I don't like cuss words and generally don't use
them. I especially don't like the F-word, although it's no more
objectionable than half a dozen others. What goes unnoticed is the
impunity with which other words _ equally coarse, equally repugnant
_ are used daily. They are not expletives, but part of a slang
whose main engine seems to be talk radio. (Skube, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Embargoed for Sunday, July 25.

   BOOK-NOTES _ Six veteran Southern authors announce their
partnership in BelleBooks, a new publishing company created to
showcase the rich storytelling traditions of Southern women. The
authors involved include Deborah Smith (who has just signed a $1.2
million deal with Little, Brown), Donna Boyd and Sandra Chastain.
(O'Briant, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BOOK-MILNER _ In the good ole summer time, according to
conventional wisdom, or what passes for it, one is supposed to
prefer reading ``light'' books, books that don't weigh heavily on
one's brain.

   The kind one supposedly should not read in the good ole summer
time, for instance, are those named on the latest Modern Library's
best nonfiction books of the century list. (Milner, Cox News
Service)

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers
